reviewText: This is a story by Truman Capote, and biographical to some extent. I read it years ago. But I'm guessing that anyone seeing this movie who didn't know who Truman Capote is would not even think of his name. It's not at all like his novels.Buddy (Eric Lloyd) was left with three aunts and an uncle in the house they inherited from their mother (Buddy's grandmother) when Buddy's parents broke up. He's been there for about two years, and has become very close to his Aunt Sook (Patty Duke), the one who is considered "slow" or "not quite right." The authoritarian of the family is his oldest aunt, Jennie (Piper Laurie), who apparently raised the others when their mother died. Bossy old thing who clearly disapproves of how close Buddy is with Sook.The story opens on Fruitcake Weather: the day every November when Sook decides it is time for her and Buddy to make their annual batch of fruitcakes for Christmas gifts. They decide that this year they must make 30 of them -- later raised to 32 as trade for the whiskey from local bootlegger to put in the cakes.The story is mostly a character study of the different somewhat odd people in this small southern town where Buddy is happy. But the crisis comes when Aunt Jennie decides he must be sent off to a military academy, since he's spending too much time with Sook, cooking and reading and flying kites and -- well, being a kid.It's a charming little story, and Buddy is a lovable kid.

reviewText: Whether it's Geraldine Page or Patty Duke playing in this fantastic film, it's always a pleasure to pop each movie into the player, come 'fruitcakeweather' each year.  The 'fruit jar' drinking glasses bring back pleasant memories of growing up in the South in the '30s and '40s...this is a delightful film for the family.

reviewText: The screenplay for this version is flawed.  By introducing characters and scenes not in the book, it changes the spirit and tone.  The actor playing the young boy is good, Patty Duke is not vulnerable enough to efface Geraldine Page's fragile and unforgettable performance.  My advice is to wait for a restored version of the original.  The only one available now is a faded black and white (color faded) version with an audio flaw. It's a crime that someone hasn't restored this masterpiece to bring it back to its original glory.

reviewText: "A Christmas Memory" is one of my favorite short stories around this time of year.  The nostalgic remembrances of a young boy's relationship with his spinster aunt is truly beautiful.  Bittersweet and poignant, this Hallmark movie version expands upon Truman Capote's autobiographical narrative to create some unforgettable characters.  Patti Duke turns in a touching performance as the childlike Suke, whose innocence and loving heart endear her to her nephew, Buddy.  Eric Lloyd turns in an unsurpassed performance as Buddy, and the chemistry between him and Duke is wonderful.  Piper Laurie is mesmerizing as Suke's practical and stern eldest sister, Jenny.  At turns, I loathed her and felt empathy toward her.  The supporting cast is equally wonderful.  I particularly liked the added plot strand of Buddy's tentative yet endearing friendship with a girl his own age named Rachel.Set during the Depression era in the Deep South, this film chronicles a Christmas season in which seven-year-old Buddy and his Aunt Suke bake fruitcakes for neighbors, family, and even strangers.  This annual project is a cherished Christmas tradition, as is decorating the tree with homemade ornaments, (Buddy's drawings of cats and fish, and angels made from Hershey's chocolate tinfoil), and the exchanging of homemade kites every Christmas morning.  The most beautiful scene in the film occurs when Buddy and Suke fly their creations on a beautiful Christmas day.  Buddy and Suke relish their time together.  However, when Suke's sister, Jenny, begins worrying that Buddy is spending too much time with his aunt, circumstance may tear them apart.This film will truly inspire you to take some time away from your frantic Christmas rush and to enter a simpler time where love and beauty were cherished.  Please give this movie a chance.  God bless you all.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The story by Truman Capote is a holiday classic with my family. Having grown up in the black and white era of television, we watched the debut (1966) of the original. Mr. Capote's narration, along with only those great actors needed for the story, makes for a great film. I was able to find the original on VHS many (many!) years ago. I gave one to my parents; and we treat it gingerly, playing it once a year at Christmas.  This new version is not as good as the original with Geraldine Page, but this newer version has very good performances by great actors.
summary: Not as good as the first, but worth a place in the collection

reviewText: Patty Duke tried awfully hard to bring Capote's classic character Cousin Suk to life in this newer screen adaptation of his famous short story.  As wonderful as Duke is, she cannot erase the memory of Geraldine Page's performance in the 1966 ABC Television production with Mr. Capote narrating.  This newer version is about a half-hour longer and introduces a number of additional characters and expands on the story.  About the only thing that is missing is the charm and simplicity of Capote's original.
summary: A NEW EDITION OF CAPOTE'S CLASSIC TALE

reviewText: It took a lot of guts for Patty Duke to take over this role that won Geraldine Page two Emmys back in the 1960s. Duke does an excellent job in making the viewer care and understand Sook and Buddy's relationship. I believe this movie has been put down because people feel it should have been left alone, but why not have a whole new generation enjoy one of the most-loved Christmas tales ever written? I also prefer not having Capote's voice-over narration in this one. As much as I am a fan of his work, his voice in the original was very obnoxious and I feel distracted from the story.Besides Duke, Piper Laurie and Eric Lloyd (Buddy) also turn in top-rate performances. I was in shock this received not a single Emmy nomination, especially not for Duke or Laurie. I am very happy to see this one coming out on DVD and plan on ordering several for Christmas gifts this year.

reviewText: I saw this film several years ago when it originally aired on television, and I loved it.  I was so excited to get it on DVD.  What a wonderful, heartwarming tale.I will say that I never saw the original with Geraldine Page.  That being said, I believe Patty Duke's performance was unbelievable.  She was amazing in a very understated way.  She makes the audience fall in love with Sook after only a few minutes.  The relationship between her and Buddy (played nicely by Eric Lloyd) is evident from the beginning.Piper Laurie also turns in a very fine performance, but it is really Patty Duke who shines in this wonderful film.

reviewText: Based on one of the all-time classic pieces of modern christmas literature, this TV movie version of the heartwarming Truman Capote tale of a young boy and his child-like older relative is devoid of any heart or warmth that was associated with the original story.  Overacted, overwritten and overdone, it seems such a shame that hollywood could not have let this simple timeless tale be a sweet 30 minute special rather then dragging it out to 90 minutes of convoluted rubbish.  Back in 1966 ABC did just that with a 30 minute version of "A Christmas Memory" starring Geraldine Page in a touching and poignant performance.  As for me, I was able to locate a hard to find a copy of the 1966 version and with it's help have been able to erase this forgettable version of  "A Christmas Memory" from my memory.
